17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

**Breakfast:** Fried potatoes, beefsteak, hot biscuits, oatmeal, coffee

**Dinner:** Roast or boiled beef, potatoes/vegetable, pickle, gravy, pie or pudding or a real New England dinner often and lots of beans, coffee

**Supper:** Beef steak, potatoes, veg, fruit, cake, coffee

---

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Montana?

...1926.............Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

**Roast chicken**, dressing, gravy, vegetables, fruit cake—pickles, pudding.

Our cowboys from all our camps were our guests.

---

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No indeed we were not, although in the winter 1906-07 our supplies ran low and our supplies were brought in spring & fall by freight wagons.

The homesteaders started to grow their own crops in 1908.
Breakfast - Fried potatoes, fried beans, oatmeal, coffee, toast or boiled beef, pudding or a meal New England style.

Dinner - Dinner and lots of brown coffee, pickles, gravy, pie or pudding.

Supper - Beef steak, potatoes, ice cream, fruit cake, kielbasa, pudding.

Our cowboy from all our campfire stories.

19. Were you ever refused to have starvation level living on you at any time? Although my locally produced food was not enough.

No, indeed we were not. Although our supplies were low.

The winter of 1906-7 our supplies were low.

Our supplies were through in spring and fall by freight only.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

As you will see we had very hearty breakfasts. In later years men did not care for their beef steak and biscuits for breakfast nor such hearty suppers.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

About 1913 - a railroad came between us and main line of C.P.R. and we could get fresh fruit and more luxuries.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

This has been over a period of time starting in 1906 - we have of course seen a great change in this South Western East. We were ranchers and lived on a good sized ranch while I did not do all the cooking I did a great deal of it. The homesteader started to go south of our ranch in 1909. By 1912 our lives had changed altogether. The country was taken over by farmers. We ranchers were confined to leases which were fenced and so our pioneer days were ended we had to become fully civilized.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the spring. (Keep an employee's lunch book.)

As you will see we had very hearty breakfasts. In early years men did not care for their heavy steak and biscuits for breakfast nor such hearty suppers.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home preserved foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

About 1918—a railroad came between us and main line of C.P.R., and we could get fresh fruit and more supplies.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways than pioneer days in eastern Canada. Include lots not sold, mixed foods, quality, methods of purchasing, etc.

The prices have been over a period of time starting in 1906—we have seen our prices change in this district within that time. We were ranchers, and lived on a good sized ranch while I did not do all the cooking. I did a great deal of it.

The Homestead Act started to go away by our ranch in 1909. By 1918 our lives had changed altogether. The country was taken over by farmers. The ranchers were confined to living in which were forced, and so our pioneer days were ended we had to become fully civilized.
